section.title: getenforce and setenforce commands
section.para: The getenforce returns the current SELinux mode: Enforcing, Permissive, or Disabled.

The setenforce temporarily changes the SELinux mode to enforcing or permissive. You cannot use this command to disable SELinux. Bear in mind that the change persists only untill the next reboot. To change the state permanently, follow the description in .
where MODE_ID is 0 for the permissive mode or 1 for the enforced mode.

section.title: The semanage command
section.para: The semanage command can be used to configure parts of the policy without the need to recompile the policy from sources. The command enables you to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: manage booleans by using the boolean argument. For details about booleans, refer to .
adjust the context of files by using the fcontext argument
manage user mappings using the login argument
manage SELinux users using the user argument
manage SELinux policy modules using the module argument.

section.title: The semanage fcontext command
section.para: Using the semanage fcontext you can perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: query file context definitions
add contexts on files
add your own rules.

section.para: Changes performed to the file context using the semanage fcontext command does not require modifications or recompilation of the policy.
